fields__book_title: Feeling – Emotion – Mood. Phenomenological and pedagogical perspectives
fields__chapter_title: Atmospheres and Understanding: Past, Present and Future
fields__description_abstract: Heidegger asserts that Stimmungen, sustained moods or attunements, are the fundamental mode or medium of our being and being‐together. In this sense Stimmungen can be said to fundamentally atmospheric. It is a shared mood or atmosphere that determines the way that the world is disclosed to us—meaning that atmospheres possess a deeply epistemic, hermeneutic dimension. If every atmosphere brings with it a shared interpretation of the world, then one needs to share or participate in this atmosphere in order to share in knowledge or learning. Only when a Stimmung suitable to such disclosure has been cultivated or encountered will the sought‐after knowledge “dawn” on one, as Bollnow puts it (2017, p. 1414; 1956, p. 57). It goes without saying that Bollnow’s statement has significant implications for pedagogy, for teaching and learning as fundamentally atmospheric experiences, and these are explored in this paper. But I begin by discussing the elusive epistemology of the atmospheric itself—what we are able to know about how we know, what access we have to the atmospheric, to the mode of our being and knowing. Then, through an illustrative video example, I go on to discuss what can be seen to make an atmosphere, a shared way of knowing, specifically pedagogical.

fields__author_editor_of_larger_work: Cristina Hanganu-Bresch, Michael J. Zerbe, Gabriel Cutrufello, and Stefania M. Maci
fields__book_title: Routledge Handbook of Scientific Communication
fields__chapter_title: Expanding Expertise in Communicating Science through Public and Citizen
fields__description_abstract: Scientific expertise is often seen as the purview of the makers of Western scientific knowledge: the professionals in labs and in the field who hold academic credentials. However, scientific practitioners can and should recognize and incorporate expertise and knowledge from those outside this realm, such as Indigenous traditions and experiential knowledge, which is what citizen science or public science works toward. This chapter examines the nature of citizen science and public science and what it means for the creation and communication of scientific knowledge. Public science acknowledges that the Public Appreciation of Science and Technology (PAST) model, which emphasizes one-way communication between scientific experts and the general public, does not allow for dynamic engagement of the public in scientific enterprises. However, the Critical Understanding of Science in Public (CUSP) model provides a framework for civic engagement and a more democratic society through scientific knowledge production. If science communication not only aims to transmit knowledge but contribute to a just, democratic society and a critical, educated public, it must acknowledge the essential roles of citizen scientists and public science. Thus, this chapter takes up the possibilities for science to account for a broader understanding of public engagement, scientific expertise, and what it means to communicate science.

fields__description_abstract:
This is an article on a revision of the system of set/class theory described by the author in an earlier publication.  It contains substantial new results:  the revised theory is quite different.

I describe this as accepted on the basis of conversation with the editor and a positive referees report, but the process of bringing this volume out seems to be disrupted by the pandemic.

Writing in Spring 2022, this has officially been confirmed as accepted.

fields__book_title: Companion to Herman Melville
fields__chapter_title: Books and Marginalia, Real and Virtual
fields__description_abstract: The growth and dispersal of Melville’s library and the roles of books and reading in his intellectual and creative experience have occupied a prominent place in Melville scholarship since the pioneering work of Merton M. Sealts, Jr., from the 1940s through the 1990s, and of Wilson Walker Cowen in the 1960s. In the present century, the work of tracking and documenting the recovery of Melville’s books, and of electronically editing his marginalia in surviving volumes, is carried on at Melville’s Marginalia Online. Whereas many important volumes owned by Melville remain lost, copies marked and annotated in his hand continue to resurface, with sporadic impacts of new evidence on scholarship devoted to this thought and craft. Current advancements in digital technology assist and expand our comprehension of old and new evidence, offering significant opportunities for the study of Melville’s reading life.

fields__book_title: Populism and its Limits: After Articulation
fields__chapter_title: Beyond Reason: The Subject of Desire and Enjoyment in Populism
fields__description_abstract: In this article the authors use the current surge of populist fervor in many parts of the world as an occasion to rethink some dominant views in contemporary Critical Theory about populism and the structure of society.  Engaging Freudian and Lacanian psychoanalysis, Hegelian and Husserlian phenomenology, and debates between Ernesto Laclau and Slavoj Zizek, the authors argue for a more fundamental role for agonal acts of desire and enjoyment over contracts of reason in the prevailing theories of society and populism.  Focusing on the subject of desire in this way helps understand the play of ideologies in our times as heavily marked by signs of embodiment and temporality and arranged around unconscious enjoyment or jouissance.

fields__author_editor_of_larger_work: Kathryn West and Linda Trinh Moser
fields__book_title: Critical Insights: AmyTan
fields__chapter_title: From "No Name Woman" to Gu Liu Xin: Ghosts and Writing in The Bonesetter's Daughter"
fields__description_abstract:
From “No Name Woman” to Gu Liu Xin: 
Ghost Writing in Amy Tan’s The Bonesetter’s Daughter

In the epilogue to The Bonesetter’s Daughter, Amy Tan offers a scene that combines the adult writer, Ruth Young, at her desk developing a story with the writer’s childhood memory of writing messages from a ghost on a tea-tray lined with sand. By fusing the two in one scene, Tan provides an apt metaphor for the work she performs throughout her fiction, that of investigating and reclaiming aspects of the past in order to define the self, align it with female ancestors, and orient it toward the future. The image of the daughter at the tea-tray writing out messages from the dead symbolizes the “possession” of the daughter by her ghostly female ancestor. This possession is not a passive state but an active one, for the daughter exercises her agency as a writer by using her imagination and responding through her written words to the to her mother about Precious Auntie.
Moreover, the story of Precious Auntie in The Bonesetter’s Daughter may be interpreted as a creative adaptation of “No Name Woman,” the first chapter of Maxine Hong Kingston’s The Woman Warrior. Tan borrows the topos of the patriarchal silencing of women from Kingston as well as the imagery of paper and ink to recover the silenced female ancestor.
In The Bonesetter’s Daughter, the fact that the family manufactures ink is a critical feature of LiLing’s childhood experience and her relationship with Precious Auntie.  Given that ink is the means by which Precious Auntie tries to kill herself (the first time) and instead injures and disfigures herself, it is also a primary element in the plot of Precious Auntie’s life story. LiLing’s calligraphy and Ruth’s own work as a writer are part of the family of images relating to writing in the novel. 
These images provide a strong parallel to the writing metaphors in “No Name Woman” and “White Tigers,” the first two chapters of Kingston’s Woman Warrior.  In “No Name Woman,” Kingston figures her memoir about her anonymous aunt as a tribute or homage, taking the place of origami offerings to the dead. In “White Tigers,” Kingston portrays the long section in which Maxine “becomes” Fa Mu Lan as an imaginative entering into an ink drawing, a passage that focuses on the similarity between the image of a bird in flight with that of the Chinese ideograph for “human.” This image symbolizes Kingston’s active engagement with the tale of Fa Mu Lan in her work as a writer.  In turn, Tan’s adaptation and revision of Kingston’s anonymous aunt in The Bonesetter’s Daughter similarly foregrounds images of writing. Tan does so in order to transfigure the anonymous aunt, a deliberately forgotten female ancestor, into a mother with a name and life story.

Jeff Westover (jeffreywestover@boisestate.edu)
182 E Gettysburg St., Boise, ID 83706     
208.598.6566

fields__author_editor_of_larger_work: Dr. Stephen Jackowicz Dr. Ismail Sahin
fields__book_title: Online Education during the COVID-19 Pandemic: Issues, Benefits, Challenges, and Strategies
fields__chapter_title: The Global Impact of the Covid-19 Pandemic and Online Learning: A Multinational Study
fields__description_abstract:
After an unprecedented year of transformation to the educational landscape, schools are 
grappling with challenges and learning experiences that never could have been predicted. 
During times of global uncertainty, the demand for innovative learning and teaching across 
the globe must be stepped up and at the forefront of educational endeavors. The challenges 
and formidable impact of the global COVID-19 pandemic have stretched educational systems 
throughout the world to reassess their goals as students and educators are asked to teach and 
learn from home while distancing themselves from others. The opportunity to address the 
myriad challenges that we are faced with and provide a quality education for all students 
incorporating technology and innovative strategies for online learning in order to meet the 
multifaceted needs of our students requires us to revolutionize the learning experience and 
carefully address the numerous dimensions yielded by these profound changes. This chapter 
provides an overview of inputs from the field in the United States and a discussion of 
alternatives found globally. It focuses on the strategies and resources to reinvigorate 
education acknowledging that online learning is tantamount to helping our students learn. 
Interviews with educators, students and parents are presented to offer insight from various 
persprectives. Examples of research-based strategies are provided to strengthen lesson design, 
pedagogical input, and expand the knowledge of creative resources.

fields__book_title: Transatlantic Discourse in Education Research
fields__chapter_title: The necessity of translation in education: Theory and practice
fields__description_abstract: Why translate in education? English-language educational research provides little evidence to suggest that translation is important or beneficial. If the object of such research is empirical and quantitative as it so often is then it is not even necessarily dependent on any single set of linguistic representations or language. It instead speaks through numbers, graphs and charts. In this context, translation appears as an exception, as a way of making contributions of uncommon figures like Paulo Freire or Jean Piaget accessible from Portuguese or French. This chapter argues, however, that the potential value of translation in education is not a matter of access or even of cross-cultural communication. Instead, it is arguably nothing less than a question of finding a language for education that is itself explicitly educational rather than one that is primarily psychological, sociological, philosophical or historical in nature.

fields__author_editor_of_larger_work: Keith H. Brigham (University of Oklahoma) and G. Tyge Payne (Louisiana State University)
fields__book_title: The Field Guide to Family Business Research
fields__chapter_title: AN INTRODUCTION TO THE USE OF SOCIAL NETWORK ANALYSIS IN FAMILY  BUSINESS RESEARCH
fields__description_abstract: In this chapter, we present a practical, introductory guide on the use of social network analysis to examine social structures (e.g., family and organization) in family business research. We present an overview of social networks coupled with a taxonomy of social ties. Then, we discuss the basics of designing social network research with a focus on data collection and management. We conclude with an overview of three software applications utilized to analyze social network data (i.e., UCINET, Stata, and R). Throughout we include examples and illustrations specific to family business research.

fields__book_title: Introduction to Becoming an LIDT Professional
fields__chapter_title: Careers in Corporate Learning & Development
fields__description_abstract: In this chapter we first define what a learning and development (L&D) role consists of. We then discuss the keys to secure a competitive L&D role in the corporate space. The second section is dedicated to several critical elements for achieving success once you have landed a corporate role. To illustrate each principle, throughout the chapter the authors incorporate examples from our professional experience.

fields__book_title: Paul B. Thompson's Philosophy of Agriculture
fields__chapter_title: Western Livestock Production and Their Challenge to Thompson’s Food System Archetypes
fields__description_abstract: Food systems are complex and made especially so by the competing values that diverse communities attribute to them and expect from them. The four archetypes of food systems that Paul B. Thompson has conceptualized help to provide clarity to this complexity; however, the food system of livestock production in the American West does not neatly align with any of these. In this chapter, I briefly describe the archetypes and how they each align and misalign with my experiences in this food system. My readers can expect to learn a bit about the history of grazing in the West, federally managed lands, current livestock practices in the West, and how the intertwining of the three create a food system that challenges the four archetypes. Ultimately, I aim to illustrate that Western livestock production systems do not fit neatly into Thompson’s archetypes, leading to either refining the archetypes or the emergence of a fifth archetype that shares features with (but is not reducible to) the others.

fields__book_title: Marianne Moore and the Archives
fields__chapter_title: Questioning Categories to Revitalize Words: Meaning and Mottoes in the Poetry of Marianne Moore
fields__description_abstract: This essay draws on archival material published on the Marianne Moore Digital Archive. It argues that Moore investigates and questions the validity of categories in her poems and notes. Drawing on ideas from Foucault and Nietzsche, the writer argues that Moore challenges her readers to think about the limitations of human knowledge and the nature of conceptual categories. The essay addresses several reading notebooks already online as well, and it analyzes poems throughout Moore's career, including "Injudicious Gardening," "A Fool, A Foul Thing, A Distressful Lunatic," "Conseil to a Bachelor," "The Student," "Frigate Pelican," "The Jerboa,"  "Then the Ermine," "Virginia Britannica," Smooth Gnarled Crape Myrtle," ""Walking-Sticks and Paperweights and Watermarks," and "The Paper Nautilus." 8682 words

fields__author_editor_of_larger_work: Bob Frodeman, Evelyn Brister, & Luther Propst
fields__book_title: A Watershed Moment
fields__chapter_title: Booming and Busting in Salmon, Idaho
fields__description_abstract:
Cobalt’s importance has taken the rural community of Salmon in central Idaho by storm. Salmon was founded after gold was struck in the nearby mountains, and has seen its fair share of mining boom-and-bust cycles. The recent activity surrounding cobalt mining is routine for this community, yet the social landscape for mining has changed. Mines now face a wide range of environmental and social considerations that add time and cost to operations, while demand increases for critical minerals to advance our technological society. It is a dilemma that takes on an unaccustomed cast when the minerals are those that support a more environmentally sustainable future. 
 These transitions present a series of juxtapositions. Cobalt mining can be environmentally destructive, yet this has to be weighed against the overall good it can do for the environment. Incoming residents looking to be closer to nature place new pressures on infrastructure and the community bonds of rural towns, but then add to the economic and cultural diversity that can help a rural community adapt to a changing world. Such juxtaposition is a reality we must face as we navigate the environmental and social changes that occur as we move toward a more environmentally sustainable future. The story of Salmon is a story of challenges and optimism that mining and social transitions can be done responsibly through the social, environmental, and economic boom-and-busts of the American West.

fields__book_title: Field Philosophy East and West
fields__chapter_title: Limits to Collaboration: Field Philosophy Working Lands in the West
fields__description_abstract:
This essay is an example of field philosophy. Field philosophy throws itself into a particular issue or case, rather than merely applying theory or entering with abstract notions of the problem. Field philosophy is practiced  in situ  – the philosophy is not an abstract dimension of the situation, but is the medium within which the situation occurs. It views philosophy as a lived practice as much as an intellectual endeavor. Reporting on field philosophy will always be understated; the context it is practiced in is too rich – too saturated – to fully recognize in spoken language. 
 My case is livestock grazing on a family ranch in Northeastern Nevada. Through the seven years I’ve been working with the ranch, I’ve come to recognize the role of federal land governance in enacting (always imperfectly) varying conceptions of democracy and the ways that structured epistemic projects serve to curate diverging democratic ideals. This is the medium within which my practice occurs. Here, I report on the ways collaboration is enacted, and how adherence to scientific discipline undermines the collaborative landscape. Along the way, readers will learn a bit about public land management and the deep-seated challenges that must be addressed to develop collaborative public land management that puts the  public  back into  public  land.

fields__book_title: The Three Body Problem and International Relations
fields__chapter_title: Wallfacers, domestic politics, and extinction: The limits of realism in intergalactic politics
fields__description_abstract: The events across the Three Body Problem trilogy paint a realist universe where Trisolaris and Earth are engaged in a complex deterrence game surrounded by unknown other actors in a dark forest. However, by examining the behavior of the wallfacers and the choices of sub-global actors, domestic political explanations become necessary to understand the choices of Earth. Finally, we conclude with the dangers of a realist frame of galactic politics and how such framing makes omnicide more, not less, likely.

fields__author_editor_of_larger_work: Ivana Salopek Cubric, Goran Cubric, Kristian Jambroxic, Tanja Lulic, Davor Sumpor
fields__book_title: Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Ergonomics
fields__chapter_title: The Ergonomics of Blood Pressure Measurement
fields__description_abstract: The most commonly used method to measure blood pressure in adults is middle upper arm sphygmomanomtery. However, different cuff-sizes can result in different pressure readings. Pressure readings will be higher for larger arm circumferences and lower for smaller arm circumferences when the same cuff is used. The goal of this study was to determine an adjustment factor that will allow measurements obtained for any combination of arm circumference and cuff size to be compared to each other. The results of this study showed that the percentage (%) value of upper arm circumference coverge by the cuff can serve as such an adjustment factor. Data obtained from nineteen test subjects showed that a 1% change in upper arm coverage results in a 1 mmHg change in both systolic and diastolic pressure readings. Using the proposed % adjustment factor allows a patient’s blood pressure to be compared to blood pressure values obtained using any combination of cuff bladder size and arm circumference. This will also allow pressure readings to be matched to the American Heart Association’s recommended upper arm coverage of 80%.

fields__book_title: F.D.E. Schleiermacher’s Outlines of the Art of Education A Translation & Discussion
fields__chapter_title: Accentuate the Negative: Schleiermacher’s Dialectic
fields__description_abstract: Schleiermacher is of the conviction—however unusual it sounds today—that education is not a matter primarily for logical analysis, normative judgment or even for empirical investigation. Education as a discipline, according to Schleiermacher, does not answer primarily to rules of logic, to fixed norms and values, or to matters of empirical fact. Education, in other words, is adequately addressed neither through normativizing critical analysis, nor through empirical investigation and assessment— arguably the two dominant discourses in educational research today. Education for Schleiermacher, as Schmied- Kowarzik (2008) writes, “is neither a normative nor an empirical discipline, but is instead a practical one which is concerned with the uncovering of dialectical interconnections…” (p. 61; emphases added). Schleiermacher himself puts it thusly: “Our observations here are not speculative but are in the strict sense of the word theoretical.” And the “strict sense” of theory— captured in the ancient Greek theoria3— “relate[s] ” above all “to a specific practice,” as Schleiermacher himself goes on to explain (above, p. 29; emphases added).

fields__author_editor_of_larger_work: Penelope Peterson, Eva Baker, Barry McGaw
fields__book_title: The International Encyclopedia of Education
fields__chapter_title: Phenomenology and education: researching pedagogical experience
fields__description_abstract: Phenomenology is the study of experience as it is concretely lived, a study that works to develop general structures or interpretations from this concrete particularity. Pedagogy, on the other hand, can be delineated through the “pedagogical difference” that separates the experience of the educator from the experience of those being educated. Phenomenology and pedagogy converge not just in their interest in particular experiences on either side of this divide; both imply a position or an “attitude” from which everyday pedagogical experience can be understood. Phenomenology is a philosophical tradition and an approach to qualitative research that has been adapted to the study of lived experience in fields as diverse as psychology, psychiatry and sociology. In both philosophy and qualitative research, phenomenology is seen as embodying a method with multiple stages or facets, known collectively as the reduction, bracketing or epoché. Today phenomenology designates an active and varied international field of research and theory, one that continues to address urgent issues and concerns in education and in a wide variety of other domains.

fields__author_editor_of_larger_work: Penelope Peterson, Eva Baker, Barry McGaw
fields__book_title: International Encyclopedia of Education
fields__chapter_title: Continental pedagogy & curriculum
fields__description_abstract: Continental Pedagogy refers to a way of thinking about educational practice that coalesced in Europe some 250 years ago and that continues to be elaborated today. Developed from the Greek paιdᾰgugῐᾱ (paidagogía; paidos ¼ child; agogos ¼ leader) and rendered as la pédagogie in French, pedagogía in Spanish and Pädagogik in German, Continental Pedagogy is based on understandings that are radically different from those taken for granted in education in the English-speaking world. Continental Pedagogy sees education as being primarily concerned neither with school and curricula, nor with the pedagogy in the English sense of the techniques and politics of teaching (Friesen, 2019). Instead, it begins with the insight that education and pedagogy are both about the influence that is exercised by one person or group (i.e., the educator) on another (i.e., the educand), and that this influence exists in special relation to the world. The resulting configuration of self, other and world forms what has been called the “pedagogical triangle” (Fig. 1; e.g., see: Briançon, 2019). Within this configuration, pedagogy is particularly concerned with the personal experience of the educand with the educator (i.e., the pedagogical relation; Friesen, 2017) and with the educand’s relationship with the world (Bildung, formación, le formation).

fields__book_title: Teaching UX: A Process Approach
fields__chapter_title: Teaching Accessibility Through UX Design
fields__description_abstract: UX design infiltrates the practice of technical and professional (TPC) communication because its principles align with the goal of TPC to prioritize the needs of the user. UX goals ask the designer to not only consider if the product is usable but also to consider the experience of that use through innovative thinking (Tham, 2022). This type of design process requires a hyper collaborative relationship with the user and demands the designer relinquish the role of expert to center the user in the design space. Accessibility, the process of ensuring equal access to technologies and information (Oswal, n.d.), aligns with these UX goals. Both UX and accessibility design require the designer to think outside of their own experiences and beyond traditional design, which is why the process begins with empathy. UX invites the designer to emerge in the perspective of the user with a truly open mind attempting to understand how users live in their daily lives (Kelley with Littman, 2005). Using a graduate student technical communication course as a backdrop, this chapter offers methods and benefits for instructors to place UX principles, accessibility practices, and service learning in concert within the technical communication to teach future practitioners the benefit of dispersed power and hyper collaboration. In the course, students are challenged to develop accessible designs with a variety of community partners with disabilities. Students practice user research methods, including interviewing and observation, to understand the access needs these users face in an area of daily living. Students use this data and flexible interaction with their users to inform how they define the need, design the product, and then evaluate, iterate, and implement their designs. As part of this process, students keep reflection journals to capture their own experiences in the UX design space. Students also conference with the instructor at regular intervals. Although there are challenges such as managing community partners, logistics, and scheduling, overwhelmingly, the greatest challenge students encountered was the inability to let go of their own assumptions regarding access solutions and let the user’s experience guide the design process. Students often “solved” the user’s need from their own perspective rather than the lived experience of access for the user. The restructuring of the expert/novice relationship is not an easy transition for students to accomplish in the classroom environment. The dynamics of the classroom typically demand students illustrate their expertise by knowing the “right” method and skill to use to design the “correct” product. The process of centering the user and asking the student to relinquish the role of expert felt disorienting at times. And yet this dynamic, interactive but sometimes uncomfortable relationship is invaluable to accessible, usable designing. In order to facilitate students’ ability to value and practice their dual role of expert and novice requires high-touch guidance from the instructor, which might take the shape of frequent student interviews. The goals of these interactions include students recognizing missteps and forming pathways to revisit their empathy work, which often meant new research, defining, evaluating and iterating. More importantly, these sessions guide students to trust the UX design process and to view accessibility as an experience of the user rather than a list of guidelines. With intentional guidance, students learn UX is not a clean, formulaic process. It is beautifully messy because it engages with the infinite, dynamic diversity of the human experience.

fields__author_editor_of_larger_work: Carmen Dagostino, Marianne Mithun, and Keren Rice
fields__book_title: The Languages and Linguistics of Indigenous North America: A Comprehensive Guide
fields__chapter_title: Clause-Combining: Relative Clauses
fields__description_abstract: This chapter presents a survey of constructions in the languages of Native North America that could properly be considered relative clauses. Relative clauses are subordinate clauses or clause-like structures that describe nouns and either fully occupy the position of a noun phrase in a sentence or appear as dependents of a noun phrase, either modifying or delimiting the head noun or associated statement. From the perspective of language acquisition, one may consider the primary function of a restrictive relative clause as assisting the speaker in directing the attention of the listener to a particular entity or type—an identifying function.

fields__book_title: Applicative Constructions in the World's Languages
fields__chapter_title: Applicatives in Northern Uto-Aztecan Languages
fields__description_abstract: Applicative constructions in Northern Uto-Aztecan (NUA) languages, although dissimilar in form, share many functional-semantic features and similar historical developments. All NUA languages carry a verb suffix signaling the addition of a bene- factive argument to the organic valence. In most cases, they represent the only means for expressing a beneficiary as a core argument. Applicative suffixes in NUA appear in most cases to originate from a ‘give’ verb. Although not always noted as such in the available grammatical descriptions, NUA applicative constructions show causative-ben- efactive syncretism associated with semantic verb type. The benefactive function is quite consistent with transitive and active (agentive) intransitives, whereas with stative (or patientive) intransitive verbs, the suffix functions as a causative. In languages that have distinct applicative forms and morphological causatives, their frequency of use still follows this pattern.

fields__book_title: Marginalized Voices and Figures in French Festival Culture, 1500-1800, European Festival Studies, 1450-1700
fields__chapter_title: Ritual Resistance: Festival Conflicts in Wallonia during the French Revolutionary E  ra (1786-1830)
fields__description_abstract:
Francophone Belgium has a rich tradition of popular festivals dating back to the fourteenth century, including saint military marches, processionals of ‘giants’ (massive puppets), and carnival celebrations. Between 1786-1830, Wallonian communities marginalized by foreign occupation sought to defend and preserve these traditions. Evolving over centuries into elaborate public ceremonies, the religious origins of these festivals were eclipsed in the eighteenth century by secular tropes and enthusiastic popular participation. Emperor Joseph II attempted to regulate festival culture in 1786, a decision that engendered significant resistance and was a leading catalyst for Belgian revolt against Austrian rule during the Brabantine Revolution. In the French Revolutionary era, during which festivals with Catholic origins were banned and replaced with commemorations of the French Republic, the preservation of these folkloric traditions was a focal point for Belgian popular resistance. After Napoleon’s defeat at Waterloo, the Dutch annexation of Belgian provinces brought still more foreign regulation, continuing the centralized restrictions on festival life that originated during the Austrian and French eras of occupation.    
 Historical research for this period of festival culture in Belgium has not received significant attention beyond isolated studies centered on specific festivals. This chapter analyzes how the proponents of these festivals weathered widespread regulation and outright bans of what were historically liturgical processionals across the Wallonian province of Hainaut, and how what began as religious rituals espoused by ecclesiastical elites became populist symbols of unity and resistance. Popular voices were not often included in the historical record of early modern Belgium and when they appear in archival documents, it is often as protest to elites – either provincial governments or the regency administrators of various foreign occupiers, including Austrians, French, and Dutch. Ultimately, this study centers on how ordinary people in these communities experienced and defended Wallonian festival culture during a critical fifty-year period when regulation and interdiction threatened to destroy traditional celebrations in Hainaut.

fields__book_title: "Survival Through Education:" On the Topicality of Heinz-Joachim Heydorn's Philosophy of Education
fields__chapter_title: Heydorn in the Anthropocene: Humanity & Nature,  Bildung  & Survival
fields__description_abstract: As Joachim Heydorn notes, his 1974 Überleben durch Bildung was writ-ten during a time of great “peril” (Gefärdung), in the middle of the Cold War, with the survival of humanity in the balance. The path leading away from this grave peril, Heydorn argues, is Bildung. It offers not only an escape from imminent danger, but also from dehumanization: “humanity cannot bear a dehumanized survival,” Heydorn writes in concluding his text: “Society must be formed [gebildet] in such a way that it knows its human purpose and the danger in which it finds itself. The path between [purpose] and peril must be found.” (1974: 273). Today, the conditions of the Anthropocene mean that the survival of the human race is again radically open to question. The threat in this case, however, is neither dehumanization nor nuclear destruction (although these remain im-portant); it is instead environmental degradation and catastrophic climate change. And Bildung—especially in this broad sense of coming to know about oneself and one’s condition—is clearly relevant to it. But this is certainly not a Bildung that, as Heydorn remarks, represents “the pro-gressive liberation of humanity to itself” (p. 273) and that is centered only on human purpose.

fields__author_editor_of_larger_work: Michael Johnson; Felicity Healey-Benson; Catherine Adams; Nina Bonderup Dohn
fields__book_title: Phenomenology in Action for Researching Networked Learning
fields__chapter_title: Networked Learning, Teaching, and Normativity: A Phenomenological Deconstruction
fields__description_abstract: To speak of “networked learning” (e.g., NLEC, 2021a) is to subsume a wide range of educational questions under two overdetermined rubrics. “Learning” and “networked” are words that already carry a heavy semantic burden in both educational and technological discourses. First, the word “learning”—as used in networked learning and in educational discourse generally—tends to conflate the roles and responsibilities of student and teacher. Second, and again as in educational discourse broadly, the definitions provided for networked learning fail to clearly distinguish between “is” and “ought,” between description and prescription. The task of carefully defining networked learning is justified as providing “a concise description of a field of research and practice” but relies on normative criteria that have no unambiguous descriptive corollaries. Third and finally, to speak of experi-ences as “networked” is to direct attention to structured, interconnected, or entangled manifestations of learning. This is incompatible with the ontological presuppositions of phenomenology and with phenomenological accounts of learning as “non-disponible:” inaccessible, non-available, and non-controllable.

fields__book_title: Militarized Landscapes
fields__chapter_title: Pushing back against the global: The effect of environmental protests on U.S. military deployments abroad
fields__description_abstract: The global U.S. military network is an unparalleled security arrangement that has allowed the United States to project military force in every geopolitical region. By stationing its troops abroad, the United States has effectively outsourced many of the inevitable environmental consequences of its unique military position. Activists have noticed this particular consequence of basing and have mobilized against it in several countries. Our study takes a multimethod approach to assess the effect of these movements. To assess whether protests have been effective in changing the deployments by the United States, we employ a textual review of available Status of Forces Agreements, a case study of the protest movements in Vieques and Okinawa, and a large observational study of the effect of protests on the concentration of U.S. forces in other countries. While there has been some success in local movements, the overall effect of protests has been minimal thus far.

fields__book_title: Geographies of Displacement/s
fields__chapter_title: Environmental displacement in the Anthropocene
fields__description_abstract: This intervention invites more substantial scholarly attention to human displacement in and of the Anthropocene—this current epoch in which humans have become the primary drivers of global environmental change—and sets out an initial framework for its study. The framework is organized around three interrelated contributions. First is the recognition that displacement is driven not just by climate change but also broader forms of environmental change defining the Anthropocene, including biodiversity loss, changes to land and water resources, and the buildup of nuclear debris, along with their intersections. Second, the framework parses out three distinct moments of displacement in the Anthropocene: displacement as a consequence of, prerequisite to, and active response to environmental change. Third, the framework rejects environmental (neo)determinism by showing how displacement across these distinct moments and drivers is more than environmental: It is the articulation of environmental and sociopolitical–economic factors, which are routinely shaped by inequality and play out within a broader series of crises and crisis narratives that drive displacement and hinder viable solutions. We ground these interventions in examples of political conflict, anti-immigrant politics, the posttruth and colonial politics of knowledge production, and the Anthropocene itself as crisis requiring displacement to clean up its mess. Although each example is quite distinct, a common thread stitched across them is colonialism, highlighting a recurring extra-environmental driver of displacement. Taken together, these dynamics underscore that displacement is not an unfortunate by-product of the Anthropocene but woven into its very fabric.

fields__book_title: Global Cultures: Engaging Diasporas Around the World in Diverse  Contexts
fields__chapter_title: Future-Proofing the Cultural Sector: Assessing Climate Risk and Actualizing the UN SDGs
fields__description_abstract: Climate Change presents numerous risks to museums, and more broadly, to the preservation of essential cultural heritage assets around the world. Severe weather, flooding, fires, amplified humidity, increases in energy and utility costs, in addition to the reputational risks of inaction and the resulting negative impacts on communities, all constitute direct and indirect forms of risk. Consequently, in addition to educating and inspiring visitors toward a regenerative and equitable future, museums are equally tasked with revising operational planning to meet the ethical expectations of stakeholders and realities of altered ecosystems. These efforts include evaluating and updating internal operations to both mitigate and adapt to the climate crisis, as well as measuring and documenting practices, impacts, and progress. As museums are working to find their place within an increasingly complex climate crisis, both in terms of interpretive responsibilities and operational challenges, many have found the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) to be a helpful NorthStar in navigating environmental and social impact management. Cultural institutions and the SDGs serve each other reciprocally. Museums preserve cultural and natural heritage and share vital stories; while the SDGs create a framework with which museums can use to connect their messages with real world change, and measure impact for accountability and SDG attainment.

fields__book_title: Psychology of Design
fields__chapter_title: How can we design to positively impact individual decision making?
fields__description_abstract: Decision making is an important skill that can be developed through well-designed learning experiences. Expert decision makers rely on an extensive content knowledge base and use different strategies from novice decision makers. People make systematic errors in their decision-making process. Normative decision-making approaches are helpful for novices, while naturalistic approaches are regularly used by experts. Effective decision-making training involves access to strong mental models, deliberate practice, quality feedback, and appropriately challenging tasks. In this chapter, the authors review key ideas related to effective human decision making.

fields__book_title: Geoenvironmental Engineering Manual of Practice (MOP) 159
fields__chapter_title: Electrokinetic Remediation
fields__description_abstract:
Using electric fields for various geotechnical and geoenvironment applications, especially  in-situ  remediation of soil contaminated with hazardous waste has become popular. There are more established methods for remediation such as the use of Direct currents (DC) and alternating current (AC) as well as more recent research on the use of electromagnetic fields (Azad et al., 2013, 2015; Farid et al., 2014). The focus of this section is on the use of DC, referred to as electrokinetic remediation. In such method, DC is applied across electrodes inserted into the soil where applying an electric potential, electric current is induced across the electrodes for mobilization and extraction of contaminants. Contaminants can be transported to extraction wells using electroosmosis and ionic migration along with electrolysis causing a series of chemical reactions. In addition to the induced flow of contaminants, electrodeposition and ion exchange (for heavy metals) can be used for heavy metal remediation. 
A constant electric field of DC can directly move any charged particle and, hence, be used to remediate any material that can be ionized (e.g., inorganics, heavy metals, and ionic radioactive compounds). Such electric field can also indirectly move and remediate noncharged (both polar or nonpolar) material (e.g., organic compounds).
